G.L. c. 186.proposition: Plaintiff has at all relevant times been a “tenant” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and Defendant has at all relevant times been a “landlord” or “lessor” within the meaning of those statutes.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Plaintiff has at all relevant times been a “tenant” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and Defendant has at all relevant times been a “landlord” or “lessor” within the meaning of those statutes.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Cambridge District Court because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in Cambridge District Court because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this Court’s territorial jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2; G.L. c. 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: The tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, guaranteeing Plaintiff’s right to the quiet, peaceful, and reasonable use and enjoyment of the Apartment without substantial interference by Defendant or those acting under his authority.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14, 18.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 60 and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff hereby demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting a tenant’s right to freedom from serious and substantial interference by the landlord or by those acting with the landlord’s permission or under the landlord’s control.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial lease case and does not discuss Massachusetts residential landlord-tenant law or any implied covenant of quiet enjoyment specific to residential leases. Its covenant-of-quiet-enjoyment analysis is in the context of constructive eviction for a commercial tenant and focuses on whether the premises were made untenantable, not on an implied covenant in every residential lease. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the stated residential-law proposition.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "We next consider whether the landlord’s actions regarding the leaky roof constituted a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment amounting to the constructive eviction of the tenant. Where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant may raise constructive eviction as a defense to an action to recover rent."

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s leasing and permitting of a lounge that created chronic noise for tenants could constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment because the landlord created or permitted the conditions leading foreseeably to the interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlords’ leasing and permitting of a lounge that generated chronic, late‑night noise for nearby residential tenants constituted a breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, even absent an intent to interfere. The court emphasized that the disturbance was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and that, because they retained the right and ability to control the lounge’s operations, they were responsible for the resulting interference. This matches the proposition’s focus on landlord-created or -permitted conditions and foreseeability.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. … [T]he landlords introduced a commercial activity into an area where they leased premises for residential purposes. … We conclude that, as matter of law, the landlords had a right to control the objectionable noise coming from the lounge….”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment may be violated by affirmative acts of the landlord or by the landlord’s failure to control conditions or activities that the landlord has the right or ability to control, where such acts or failures result in a serious interference with the tenant’s ability to use the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord’s liability can arise not only from its own affirmative acts but also from its failure to take available measures to control third-party criminal activity on property it owns and controls, where such failure results in serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises. The opinion emphasizes that quiet enjoyment is breached by what the landlord "failed to do, or permitted to be done," and applies that standard to the landlord’s omission in controlling drug activity in the common areas. This aligns directly with the proposition stated.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The interference need not be intentional or malicious; a landlord’s conduct that substantially impairs the character and value of the leased premises for the tenant’s ordinary uses can constitute a breach, even if arising out of renovations or improvements.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses whether interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires intentional or malicious conduct and concludes that malicious intent is not required; recklessness and conduct whose natural and probable consequence is interference suffice. It also defines “quiet enjoyment” in terms of serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, drawing on common-law authority, and applies that doctrine to a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions. Although the facts involve flooding rather than renovations, the legal rule stated clearly supports the broader proposition that intentional or malicious interference is not necessary for breach where the landlord’s conduct substantially impairs ordinary use.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”}

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: The prolonged and significant day‑time noise, drilling, hammering, banging, and loud talking by workers, combined with dust entering the Apartment, constitute a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not concern construction noise, dust, or similar physical interferences with occupancy. It addresses whether a statutory violation (the lead paint statute) automatically constitutes a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and holds that at least negligent conduct and landlord knowledge/notice are required. It neither discusses nor establishes that daytime construction noise and dust constitute a substantial and unreasonable interference with quiet enjoyment, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial interference with a tenant’s use of premises can entitle the tenant to relief, including rent abatement and statutory damages where the landlord’s acts or omissions fall within G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402 (.support_reasoning: The court explicitly recognizes that substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of leased premises constitutes a compensable loss of property and grounds for relief. It affirms an award of statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14 (three months’ rent) for violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, and discusses how that award interacts with rent-based damages and G.L. c. 93A remedies. The opinion therefore supports the proposition that substantial interference can entitle tenants to relief including rent-based and statutory damages under § 14.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402 (.relevant_excerpt:
“There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents…

The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment… [which] allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater.’”}

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial interference with a tenant’s use of premises can entitle the tenant to relief, including rent abatement and statutory damages where the landlord’s acts or omissions fall within G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the landlord’s negligent failure to correct serious code violations that substantially impaired the value of the premises constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 (covenant of quiet enjoyment). The court explains that a landlord violates § 14 when acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises and concludes that, on the facts, § 14 was violated and the tenant is entitled to statutory relief including attorney’s fees. This directly supports the proposition that substantial interference with a tenant’s use can entitle the tenant to relief, including statutory damages, under § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720\u201321.proposition: The prolonged and significant day‑time noise, drilling, hammering, banging, and loud talking by workers, combined with dust entering the Apartment, constitute a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. See Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (landlord liability where conditions substantially impair tenant’s use); Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03.

Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718\u201319.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment may be violated by affirmative acts of the landlord or by the landlord’s failure to control conditions or activities that the landlord has the right or ability to control, where such acts or failures result in a serious interference with the tenant’s ability to use the premises. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994); Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19.

Simon, 385 Mass. at 102\u201303.proposition: The prolonged and significant day‑time noise, drilling, hammering, banging, and loud talking by workers, combined with dust entering the Apartment, constitute a substantial and unreasonable interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law. See Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997) (landlord liability where conditions substantially impair tenant’s use); Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03.

Al\u2011Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850\u201351.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.

Doe, 417 Mass. at 284.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.
Doe, 417 Mass. at 284.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe, 417 Mass. at 284.support_reasoning: Doe deals with a landlord’s liability for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment arising from failure to take reasonable measures to curb criminal/drug activity in common areas, not from construction or renovation-related disturbances. The court’s analysis turns on the landlord’s omissions regarding security and removal of nontenants, not on control over renovations or foreseeability of disturbance from construction. Therefore, Doe does not support a proposition about renovation‑related conduct sufficing to establish a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Doe, 417 Mass. at 284.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment… We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789\u201390.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.

Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, in light of his control over the renovations and foreseeability of the disturbance, is of the type that Massachusetts courts have held sufficient to establish a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett, 371 Mass. at 718–19; Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720–21; Al‑Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850–51; Doe, 417 Mass. at 284; Cruz Mgmt. Co., 417 Mass. at 789–90; Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402; Simon, 385 Mass. at 102–03; see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 18; G.L. c. 239, § 8A.
Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402.case_name: Wingate v. Emery Air Freight Corp.
Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402.support_reasoning: Wolfberg (Wingate v. Emery Air Freight Corp.) is an evidence case about the admissibility of an employer’s injury report under the Massachusetts business records statute. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, renovations, or disturbance of tenants. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that certain conduct constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and is mis‑cited for that purpose.
Wolfberg, 385 Mass. at 402.relevant_excerpt: This appeal concerns the circumstances under which an employer's report of injury, containing an account of an accident that resulted in injury to an employee, may be introduced in evidence, despite its hearsay nature, in a tort case brought by the plaintiff employee against a third party. We…define certain limits in the application of G.L. c. 233, § 78, the so‑called business records statute.

Wesson, 437 Mass. at 721\u201323.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that substantial interference with a tenant’s use of premises can entitle the tenant to relief, including rent abatement and statutory damages where the landlord’s acts or omissions fall within G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Wesson, 437 Mass. at 721–23; Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402 (1982) (discussing remedies for landlord interference and statutory protections); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994).
